name: Late Period
notes: Refers to Egypt's Late Period, marked by foreign invasions, Saite dynasty, and Persian rule.

name: Ptolemaic Dynasty
notes: Greek-ruled Egypt; famous for Alexandria, Cleopatra VII, and the Rosetta Stone.

name: Twelfth Dynasty of Egypt
notes: Well-documented dynasty; notable rulers include Senusret III and Amenemhat III. Major advances in administration and architecture.

name: Hellenistic Greece
region: Europe, Middle East, North Africa, Central Asia, South Asia
notes: Well-documented era post-Alexander; Greek culture spread widely. Extensive archaeological and textual sources.

name: Ptolemaic Kingdom
notes: Hellenistic dynasty in Egypt, founded by Ptolemy I after Alexander the Great's death. Ended with Cleopatra VII.

name: Roman Republic
notes: Extensively documented; foundational to Western political and legal traditions.

name: Principate
notes: Early Roman Empire under emperors; Augustus to Diocletian. Extensive sources and archaeological remains.

name: Western Roman Empire
region: Southern Europe, Western Europe, North Africa
notes: Well-documented; Latin sources, archaeological remains, and detailed leadership chronology.

name: Eastern Roman Empire
notes: Also known as Byzantine Empire; extensive records, art, and architecture survive.

name: Constantinian Dynasty
notes: Roman imperial dynasty founded by Constantine the Great; pivotal for Christianity and late Roman reforms.

name: Justinian Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty; notable for Justinian I, legal reforms, Hagia Sophia, and wars with Sassanids and Germanic tribes.

name: Habsburg Dynasty
notes: Ruled Austria, Spain, and more. Extensive records, art, and architecture survive. Dynasty ended with WWI.

name: Norman Kingdom of Sicily
notes: Multicultural kingdom noted for Norman, Arab, and Byzantine influences; well-documented rulers and administration.

name: Kingdom of England
notes: Unified under Æthelstan; merged into Kingdom of Great Britain in 1707; extensive documentation.

name: Kingdom of France (Capetian)
notes: Capetian dynasty established by Hugh Capet; strong documentation and cultural legacy.

name: Valois Dynasty
notes: French royal dynasty; ruled during Hundred Years' War, Renaissance; extensive documentation and cultural legacy.

name: Bourbon France
notes: Bourbon dynasty ruled France from Henry IV to the French Revolution; rich documentation and cultural legacy.

name: Republic of Venice
notes: Major maritime republic; extensive archives, art, and architecture survive. Ended with Napoleon's conquest.

name: Papal States (Renaissance)
notes: Extensive records exist; Papal States were a major Renaissance power with clear leadership and rich cultural legacy.

name: Papal States (Early Modern)
notes: Well-documented theocratic state under papal rule; extensive archives and material culture survive.

name: Crown of Castile
notes: Major medieval/early modern Spanish kingdom; key in Reconquista and Spanish unification.

name: Crown of Aragon
notes: A major medieval and early modern polity; rich records in Catalan, Aragonese, Latin, and Spanish.

name: Habsburg Spain
notes: Ruled by Habsburg dynasty; global empire; extensive documentation and cultural legacy.

name: Bourbon Spain
region: Europe, South America, North America, Caribbean
notes: Bourbon dynasty ruled Spain after 1700, influencing politics, reforms, and colonial administration.

name: Kingdom of Portugal (1139–1910)
notes: Well-documented monarchy; pivotal in global exploration, colonial empire, and European politics.

name: Kingdom of Poland (elective monarchy)
notes: Elective monarchy formed after Union of Lublin; ended with Third Partition. Rich documentation and cultural legacy.

name: Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth
notes: A major European state, known for its elective monarchy and religious tolerance. Partitioned by neighbors in the late 18th century.

name: Habsburg Monarchy
region: Europe, Central Europe, Western Europe, Eastern Europe, Southern Europe
notes: Ruled by the Habsburg dynasty, major European power; extensive records and cultural legacy.

name: Kingdom of Hungary (1867–1918)
notes: Part of Austro-Hungarian Empire; extensive documentation and cultural records available.

name: Archduchy of Austria
notes: Key Habsburg territory; became Austrian Empire in 1804. Extensive documentation and cultural legacy.

name: Austro-Hungarian Empire
region: Central Europe, Eastern Europe, Southern Europe
notes: Multi-ethnic empire; dual monarchy of Austria and Hungary; dissolved after WWI.

name: Swiss Confederation (Federal State)
notes: Modern federal state established 1848; multilingual, stable democracy, extensive documentation.

name: Dutch Republic
notes: Known for maritime power, trade, and art. Extensive records in Dutch and other languages.

name: Old Babylonian Kingdom
notes: Well-documented via cuneiform tablets; famous for Hammurabi and his law code.

name: Neo-Assyrian Empire
notes: Well-documented empire with extensive cuneiform records, monumental architecture, and detailed king lists.

name: Abbasid Caliphate
region: Middle East, North Africa, Central Asia, South Asia
notes: Extensive documentation; major Islamic Golden Age polity; capital at Baghdad; major scientific and cultural advances.

name: Fatimid Caliphate
notes: Ismaili Shia dynasty; founded in Ifriqiya, later ruled Egypt; Cairo established as capital; major cultural and economic influence.

name: Mamluk Sultanate
notes: Well-documented sultanate; ruled Egypt, Levant. Extensive Arabic sources and material remains.

name: Ottoman Empire
region: Europe, Asia, Middle East, North Africa
notes: Extensive records, clear sultanic lineage, rich material and written culture, major world power for centuries.

name: Mamluk Dynasty
notes: Ruled Egypt and Syria; known for defeating Mongols and Crusaders; rich architectural and documentary legacy.

name: Western Han
notes: Extensive records, archaeological finds, and external contacts. Major dynasty in Chinese history.

name: Eastern Han
notes: Well-documented Chinese dynasty; extensive historical records and archaeological finds.

name: Tang Dynasty
notes: Golden age of Chinese culture, cosmopolitan capital Chang'an, major influence on East Asia.

name: Later Han
notes: Also known as Eastern Han; extensive records, artifacts, and influence on Chinese history.

name: Northern Song
notes: Well-documented Chinese dynasty; major advances in technology, economy, and culture. Ended with Jurchen conquest.

name: Southern Song
notes: Well-documented Chinese dynasty; rich sources in Chinese and other languages.

name: Yuan Dynasty
notes: Founded by Kublai Khan, the Yuan unified China under Mongol rule; extensive records and artifacts survive.

name: Ming Dynasty
notes: Well-documented Chinese dynasty, renowned for cultural, technological, and architectural achievements.

name: Goryeo
notes: Unified Korean dynasty; known for celadon pottery, Buddhism, and civil service exams.

name: Joseon
notes: Well-documented Korean dynasty; extensive records, art, and surviving architecture.

name: Nara Period
notes: First permanent Japanese capital at Nara; Buddhism flourished; detailed records and artifacts survive.

name: Heian Period
notes: Japanese era marked by imperial court culture, literature (e.g., Tale of Genji), and rise of samurai.

name: Kamakura Shogunate
notes: First shogunate in Japan; marked by samurai rule, Mongol invasions, and feudal governance.

name: Ashikaga Shogunate
notes: Ruled Japan during the Muromachi period; known for samurai culture, Zen Buddhism, and flourishing arts.

name: Azuchi–Momoyama Period
notes: Transitional era in Japan marked by Oda Nobunaga, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, and the rise of Tokugawa Ieyasu.

name: Nguyễn dynasty
notes: Last imperial dynasty of Vietnam; extensive records, architecture, and cultural legacy remain.

name: Kingdom of Hawaii
notes: Unified by Kamehameha I; overthrown in 1893. Rich documentation in Hawaiian and English.

name: New Kingdom of Egypt
notes: Well-documented period; pharaohs, temples, and tombs extensively studied. Hieroglyphic sources and archaeology are abundant.

name: Classical Greece
notes: Extensive sources: literature, inscriptions, archaeology. Covers city-states like Athens, Sparta, Thebes.

name: Macedonian Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty, marked by territorial expansion and cultural flourishing. Sources in Greek and other languages.

name: Palaiologan Dynasty
notes: Last ruling dynasty of Byzantine Empire; extensive records, art, and foreign accounts exist.

name: Swiss Confederation (Restored Confederacy)
notes: Post-Napoleonic Swiss Confederation restored by Congress of Vienna; led to modern federal state in 1848.

name: Achaemenid Empire
region: Asia, Middle East, Europe, North Africa
notes: Extensive Persian empire; well-documented administration, monuments, and sources in multiple languages.

name: Sasanian Empire
notes: Well-documented Persian empire; rich archaeological and textual sources; clear dynastic succession.

name: Umayyad Caliphate
region: Middle East, North Africa, Europe, South Asia, Central Asia
notes: First major Islamic dynasty; capital in Damascus; vast records and archaeological remains.

name: Safavid Empire
notes: Major Persianate dynasty; established Twelver Shi'ism as state religion; extensive art, architecture, and documentation.

name: Samanid Empire
notes: Persianate dynasty; key in Islamic Golden Age; revived Persian culture; capital at Bukhara.

name: Eastern Zhou
notes: Era of major philosophical schools, feudal states, and warfare; well-documented in Chinese sources.

name: Qin Dynasty
notes: Unified China under Qin Shi Huang; standardized script, currency, and laws; built first Great Wall sections.

name: Sengoku period
notes: Era of civil war in Japan; samurai, daimyo, and shogunate power struggles; well-documented in Japanese sources.

name: Colonial Period
region: Africa, Asia, Europe, North America, South America, Oceania, Caribbean, Central America
notes: Refers to European colonial rule globally; timelines vary by region and colonial power.

name: Crisis of the Third Century
notes: Period of Roman Empire instability: civil wars, invasions, economic crisis, and short-lived emperors.

name: Heraclian Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty; major reforms, wars with Sassanids and early Islamic Caliphates; Greek main language.

name: Komnenian Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty; revitalized empire after crisis, notable emperors include Alexios I, John II, Manuel I.

name: Valentinianic Dynasty
notes: Roman imperial dynasty founded by Valentinian I; ruled Western and Eastern Roman Empires.

name: Theodosian Dynasty
notes: Roman imperial dynasty; ruled Eastern and Western Empires. Well-documented reigns and major events.

name: Leonid Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty founded by Leo I; period includes significant political and military events.

name: Hohenstaufen Dynasty
notes: German dynasty ruling the Holy Roman Empire; notable emperors include Frederick I Barbarossa and Frederick II.

name: Papal States (Restoration and Risorgimento)
notes: Restored after Napoleonic era; lost territory during Italian unification. Papal rule ended with Rome's capture in 1870.

name: Grand Duchy of Moscow
notes: Precursor to Tsardom of Russia; extensive chronicles, architecture, and legal codes survive.

name: Přemyslid Dynasty
notes: Ruled Bohemia and Moravia; well-documented dynasty; ended with Wenceslaus III's death.

name: Jagiellonian Dynasty
notes: Ruled Poland, Lithuania, Hungary, and Bohemia; well-documented dynasty with extensive sources.

name: Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)
notes: Post-WWI kingdom under regency; significant WWII involvement; extensive documentation available.

name: State of the Teutonic Order
region: Eastern Europe, Northern Europe, Central Europe
notes: German crusader state; major role in Baltic Christianization. Ended as secular Duchy of Prussia in 1525.

name: Kingdom of Ugarit
notes: Well-documented via cuneiform tablets; known for trade, diplomacy, and early alphabet.

name: Chola Dynasty
notes: Tamil sources, inscriptions, and foreign accounts provide rich detail on Chola administration, culture, and maritime activity.

name: Hoysala Empire
notes: Renowned for ornate temple architecture; ruled Karnataka; extensive inscriptions in Kannada and Sanskrit.

name: Cao Wei
notes: One of the Three Kingdoms, founded by Cao Pi after Han. Well-documented in Chinese sources.

name: Western Jin
notes: Unified China after Three Kingdoms; ended by invasions and internal strife. Extensive historical records available.

name: Later Tang
notes: One of the Five Dynasties, ruled northern China; strong documentation in Chinese sources.

name: Ayutthaya Kingdom
notes: Major Siamese kingdom; rich records, architecture, and foreign accounts. Destroyed by Burma in 1767.

name: Spanish Colonial Period
region: Europe, North America, South America, Caribbean, Africa, Asia, Oceania
notes: Extensive documentation exists on Spanish colonial rule, administration, and cultural impact across multiple continents.

name: German Colonial Period
notes: German colonies included Togoland, Cameroon, German South West Africa, German East Africa, and Pacific holdings.

name: Japanese Mandate Period
notes: Japan administered former German Pacific islands under League of Nations mandate until WWII defeat.

name: Antigonid dynasty
notes: Macedonian dynasty ruling parts of Greece and Asia after Alexander. Ended with Roman conquest at Pydna.

name: Isaurian Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty founded by Leo III; known for iconoclasm and military reforms.

name: Angelid Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty ruling during the empire's decline; overthrown in Fourth Crusade.

name: Ostrogothic Kingdom
notes: Founded by Theoderic the Great in Italy; fell to Byzantines. Well-documented in Roman and Gothic sources.

name: Carolingian Empire
region: Western Europe, Central Europe, Southern Europe
notes: Well-documented Frankish empire; Charlemagne crowned in 800. Latin sources and archaeological finds are extensive.

name: Salian Dynasty
notes: German royal dynasty; produced four Holy Roman Emperors. Well-documented in medieval sources.

name: Late Viking Age
notes: Well-documented era with sagas, chronicles, and extensive archaeological finds. Marked by expansion, trade, and Christianization.

name: Kingdom of Poland (Jagiellonian dynasty)
notes: Well-documented dynasty; union with Lithuania, Renaissance influence, and major European power.

name: First Bulgarian Empire
notes: Major medieval state; rich sources in Slavic, Greek, and Latin. Well-documented rulers and events.

name: Kingdom of Hungary (1301–1526)
notes: Well-documented medieval kingdom; major events include Ottoman wars and the Battle of Mohács.

name: Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)
notes: Period marked by Habsburg rule, Ottoman wars, and reforms; well-documented in multiple European languages.

name: Kingdom of Bohemia (Habsburg rule)
notes: Bohemia became part of the Habsburg Monarchy in 1526; Czech and German sources are extensive.

name: Kingdom of Hungary (Habsburg rule)
notes: Well-documented period; sources in Hungarian, German, Latin. Habsburgs ruled after Mohács until Austro-Hungarian Compromise.

name: Mongol Empire
notes: Largest contiguous land empire; founded by Genghis Khan; extensive records from multiple cultures.

name: Golden Horde
notes: Mongol khanate; ruled Rus', Central Asia. Extensive records, coins, architecture, and foreign accounts.

name: Tughlaq Dynasty
notes: Delhi Sultanate dynasty known for ambitious projects, shifting capitals, and extensive chronicles.

name: Chandelas of Jejakabhukti
notes: Famed for Khajuraho temples; ruled Bundelkhand. Sources include inscriptions, coins, and later chronicles.

name: Qi (Warring States period)
notes: Qi was a major state in ancient China, especially influential during the Warring States period.

name: Shu Han
notes: One of the Three Kingdoms of China, founded by Liu Bei. Well-documented in Chinese sources.

name: Liu Song dynasty
notes: First of the Southern Dynasties in China; founded by Liu Yu; extensive historical records.

name: Liang dynasty
notes: Southern Chinese dynasty, part of the Southern and Northern Dynasties period; strong Buddhist influence.

name: Northern Qi dynasty
notes: Northern Qi ruled northern China after the Eastern Wei, known for political intrigue and Buddhist patronage.

name: Sui Dynasty
notes: Unified China after centuries of division; known for Grand Canal construction and legal reforms.

name: Wu Zhou dynasty
notes: Wu Zhou was established by Empress Wu Zetian, interrupting the Tang dynasty. Well-documented in Chinese sources.

name: Liao Dynasty
notes: Khitan-led dynasty in northern China; strong documentation and archaeological finds.

name: Later Lê dynasty
notes: Vietnamese dynasty, restored independence from Ming China, saw civil wars and cultural flourishing.

name: Angkorian Period
notes: Centered on Angkor, Cambodia; famed for temples like Angkor Wat and sophisticated urban planning.

name: Classic Maya
notes: Well-documented via inscriptions, architecture, and codices; many city-states with complex dynastic histories.

name: Triple Alliance
notes: Also known as the Aztec Empire; alliance of Tenochtitlan, Texcoco, and Tlacopan.

name: Middle Kingdom
notes: Egyptian Middle Kingdom; reunification under Mentuhotep II, advances in art, literature, and administration.

name: Mali Empire
notes: Well-documented empire; famous for Mansa Musa, Timbuktu, and trans-Saharan trade routes.

name: Zanzibar Sultanate
notes: Omani Arab-ruled sultanate on Zanzibar; major Indian Ocean trade hub; ended by 1964 revolution.

name: Argead Dynasty
notes: Ruling dynasty of Macedon, culminating with Alexander the Great; well-attested in classical sources.

name: Nikephorian Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty founded by Nikephoros I; short-lived but well-documented in Byzantine sources.

name: Doukid Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty, notable rulers include Constantine X and Michael VII. Well-documented in Byzantine sources.

name: Ottonian Dynasty
notes: German dynasty ruling Holy Roman Empire; notable for church-state relations and Ottonian Renaissance.

name: Welf Dynasty
notes: Prominent German and Italian dynasty; produced kings, dukes, and electors. Extensive documentation exists.

name: Republic of Genoa
notes: Major maritime republic; extensive archives; well-documented governance, trade, and art.

name: Papal States (High Middle Ages)
notes: Papal States were governed by the Pope, with extensive documentation and influence in medieval European politics.

name: Second Bulgarian Empire
notes: Major medieval state; known for Asen dynasty, Orthodox Christianity, and resistance to Byzantines and Ottomans.

name: Serbian Empire
notes: Founded by Stefan Dušan; peaked mid-14th c.; fragmented after 1371; rich medieval sources.

name: Austrian Empire
notes: Multiethnic empire; dissolved after Austro-Hungarian Compromise. Extensive documentation and cultural legacy.

name: Hittite New Kingdom
notes: Well-documented Anatolian empire; cuneiform archives, royal lists, and treaties survive.

name: Palmyrene Empire
notes: Short-lived breakaway state led by Queen Zenobia; well-documented in Roman and local sources.

name: Rashidun Caliphate
notes: First Islamic caliphate, led by the four 'Rightly Guided' caliphs after Muhammad's death.

name: Great Seljuk Empire
notes: Turko-Persian empire; key in Islamic Golden Age; notable for Nizam al-Mulk's vizierate and the Battle of Manzikert.

name: Ilkhanate
notes: Mongol khanate in Persia; rich sources in Persian, Arabic, Chinese; notable for cultural and religious diversity.

name: Uyghur Khaganate
notes: Turkic empire replacing the Second Turkic Khaganate; capital at Ordu-Baliq; strong Chinese contacts.

name: Gupta Empire
notes: Known as India's Golden Age; advances in science, art, and literature; ruled by Chandragupta I and successors.

name: Badami Chalukya
notes: Ruled much of southern and central India; known for rock-cut temples at Badami, Aihole, and Pattadakal.

name: Sisodia Dynasty
notes: Rajput dynasty of Mewar, famed for resistance to Delhi Sultanate and Mughals; notable rulers include Rana Kumbha and Maharana Pratap.

name: Anuradhapura Kingdom
notes: Sri Lankan kingdom known for Buddhist monuments, irrigation, and extensive chronicles like the Mahavamsa.

name: Polonnaruwa Kingdom
notes: Successor to Anuradhapura; famed for irrigation, Buddhist monuments, and Chola invasions.

name: Shang Dynasty
notes: Earliest Chinese dynasty with direct archaeological evidence; known for oracle bones and bronze work.

name: Eastern Wu
notes: One of the Three Kingdoms of China, ruled by the Sun family; well-documented in Chinese sources.

name: Southern Qi dynasty
notes: Short-lived Southern Chinese dynasty; well-documented in Chinese sources; notable for political instability.

name: Southern Tang
notes: Successor state during China's Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period; known for art and literature.

name: Asuka Period
notes: Marked by Buddhism's introduction, Taika reforms, and early Japanese state formation.

name: Trần dynasty
notes: Vietnamese dynasty noted for resisting Mongol invasions and fostering Confucian culture.

name: Ming occupation of Đại Việt
notes: Ming China occupied Đại Việt after Hồ dynasty's fall; ended by Lê Lợi's Lam Sơn uprising.

name: Khmer Empire
notes: Famed for Angkor Wat; inscriptions, architecture, and Chinese records provide rich detail.

name: Taungoo Dynasty
notes: Unified much of Burma; known for military expansion and administrative reforms. Sources mainly in Burmese and some European records.

name: Postclassic Maya
notes: Postclassic Maya civilization saw city-states, codices, and contact with Spanish; many sites and artifacts survive.

name: Inca Empire
notes: Extensive archaeological remains; Quechua sources and Spanish chronicles provide substantial information.

name: United States Trust Territory Period
notes: Administered by the US under UN trusteeship; included several island groups in Micronesia.

name: Eleventh Dynasty of Egypt
notes: Reunified Egypt after First Intermediate Period; Mentuhotep II notable pharaoh; tombs and inscriptions survive.

name: Kingdom of Aksum
notes: Major Red Sea power; famed for stelae, coinage, and early Christianization. Sources include inscriptions and Greco-Roman accounts.

name: Mauretania Caesariensis (Roman province)
notes: Roman province in present-day Algeria; well-documented administration, cities, and Christian communities.

name: Solomonic Dynasty
notes: Ethiopian dynasty claiming descent from King Solomon; ruled until 1974 revolution. Early origins partly legendary.

name: Kano
notes: Kano was a major Hausa city-state and emirate, known for trade, Islamic scholarship, and its ancient city walls.

name: Katsina
notes: Prominent Hausa city-state; known for trade, scholarship, and Islamic leadership before Sokoto Caliphate conquest.

name: Kingdom of Kongo
notes: Centralized monarchy; extensive contact with Portugal; Christianity adopted; rich oral and written records.

name: Ashanti Empire
notes: Well-documented Akan state; strong oral and written sources; British colonial conquest ended independence.

name: Amorian Dynasty
notes: Byzantine dynasty; notable for Iconoclasm's end and Arab-Byzantine conflicts.

name: Merovingian dynasty
notes: Frankish dynasty ruling much of Gaul; known for early medieval politics, art, and law.

name: High Viking Age
region: Northern Europe, Western Europe, Eastern Europe
notes: Extensive archaeological finds, runic inscriptions, and contemporary chronicles document Viking activities and society.

name: Kingdom of Wessex
notes: Anglo-Saxon kingdom, key in English unification; well-documented rulers and events.

name: Kingdom of Poland (Piast dynasty)
notes: First Polish state under Piasts; sources include chronicles, archaeology, and foreign records.

name: Kievan Rus’
notes: Early East Slavic state; notable for Christianization in 988 and Mongol conquest in 1240.

name: Kingdom of Hungary (1000–1301)
notes: Well-documented medieval kingdom; Latin and Hungarian sources; clear royal lineage; significant regional influence.

name: Swiss Confederation (Helvetic Republic)
notes: French-imposed centralized state replacing the Old Swiss Confederacy; ended with Act of Mediation.

name: Old Assyrian Empire
notes: Well-documented via cuneiform tablets; notable for trade colonies and early imperial expansion.

name: Middle Assyrian Empire
notes: Well-documented empire; cuneiform records, law codes, and royal inscriptions survive.

name: Nabataean Kingdom
notes: Famous for Petra; left inscriptions, architecture, and trade records; absorbed by Rome in 106 CE.

name: Ayyubid Sultanate
notes: Founded by Saladin, the Ayyubids ruled Egypt, Syria, and parts of Arabia; known for Crusader conflicts and architectural patronage.

name: Timurid Empire
region: Central Asia, South Asia, Middle East
notes: Founded by Timur; renowned for Persianate culture, architecture, and arts; strong documentation of rulers and events.

name: Maurya Empire
notes: Well-documented empire; sources include Ashokan edicts, Greek accounts, and archaeological finds.

name: Rashtrakuta Empire
notes: Prominent Deccan dynasty, known for patronage of arts, architecture (Ellora), and multi-lingual inscriptions.

name: Western Chalukya
notes: Kannada and Sanskrit sources; notable for architecture and regional power in Deccan.

name: Medieval Pandya Kingdom
notes: Tamil sources, inscriptions, and foreign accounts provide good detail; dynasty revived several times in medieval era.

name: Kakatiya dynasty
notes: Telugu-speaking dynasty in Deccan; known for Warangal fort, tank irrigation, and resistance to Delhi Sultanate.

name: Sangama Dynasty
notes: First dynasty of Vijayanagara Empire; notable for resistance to Delhi Sultanate and fostering Hindu culture.

name: Tuluva Dynasty
notes: Third dynasty of Vijayanagara Empire; Krishnadevaraya was its most famous ruler.

name: Mughal Empire (early)
notes: Founded by Babur in 1526; early period includes Humayun and Akbar. Persian, Chagatai, and local sources.

name: Rathore Dynasty
notes: Rajput dynasty ruling Marwar (Jodhpur), Rajasthan; notable for resistance to Mughals and British.

name: Kachwaha Dynasty
notes: Rajput dynasty ruling Amber/Jaipur; notable for alliances with Mughals and architectural heritage.

name: Solanki Dynasty
notes: Ruled Gujarat and parts of Rajasthan; notable for temple architecture and patronage of arts.

name: Pala Empire
notes: Buddhist dynasty in Bengal and Bihar; notable for Nalanda University and patronage of art and learning.

name: Chu (Warring States period)
notes: Major Warring States polity; rich archaeological finds; well-documented in Chinese sources.

name: Later Shu
notes: One of the Ten Kingdoms in Sichuan during China's Five Dynasties period; well-documented in Chinese sources.

name: Northern Wei dynasty
notes: Founded by the Tuoba clan; major role in Sinicization and Buddhist art; capital at Pingcheng, later Luoyang.

name: Eastern Wei dynasty
notes: Short-lived Northern Chinese dynasty; split from Northern Wei, succeeded by Northern Qi.

name: Western Wei dynasty
notes: Short-lived successor of Northern Wei; ruled northwest China. Well-documented in Chinese sources.

name: Northern Zhou dynasty
notes: Short-lived Chinese dynasty; unified northern China before Sui. Records in Chinese sources are extensive.

name: Later Zhou
notes: Last of the Five Dynasties in China, founded by Guo Wei; short-lived but well-documented.

name: Wuyue
notes: Wuyue was a prosperous coastal kingdom during China's Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period.

name: Southern Han
notes: One of the Ten Kingdoms in southern China; capital at Guangzhou; absorbed by Song dynasty.

name: Western Xia
notes: Tangut-led dynasty in northwestern China, conquered by Mongols. Tangut script and artifacts survive.

name: Late Silla
notes: Unified Silla ruled most of the Korean Peninsula; notable for Buddhism, art, and tombs.

name: Lý dynasty
notes: Vietnamese dynasty noted for independence from China, Buddhist influence, and capital at Thăng Long (Hanoi).

name: Tây Sơn dynasty
notes: Vietnamese dynasty founded by Tây Sơn brothers; known for military reforms and defeating rivals.

name: Mataram Sultanate
notes: Javanese Islamic sultanate; key player in Java's history, later split into Yogyakarta and Surakarta.

name: Almoravid Conquest
notes: Berber dynasty; conquered Morocco, parts of Algeria, and al-Andalus. Sources in Arabic, Latin, and Berber.

name: Oba Dynasty
notes: Benin's Oba Dynasty is famed for its bronzes and centralized monarchy; disrupted by British conquest in 1897.

name: Yoruba Ifẹ Kingdom
notes: Renowned for naturalistic bronze and terracotta art; central to Yoruba civilization; oral traditions supplement written records.

name: Oyo Empire
notes: Yoruba-speaking empire; known for cavalry, political structure, and trade; fell due to internal strife and external pressures.

name: Kilwa Sultanate
notes: Swahili-Islamic sultanate on the Swahili Coast; notable for trade, architecture, and Portuguese conquest.

name: Adal Sultanate
notes: Muslim sultanate in the Horn of Africa, known for conflicts with Ethiopia and Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi's campaigns.

name: Kingdom of Dahomey
notes: Fon-speaking kingdom known for military organization, female warriors, and role in Atlantic slave trade.

name: Seleucid Empire
notes: Hellenistic state founded after Alexander's empire split; ruled much of Near East; Greek and local sources available.

name: Dominate
notes: Assuming reference to the Roman Dominate, late Roman Empire phase; sources are substantial but fragmentary.

name: Laskarid Dynasty
notes: Byzantine Greek dynasty ruling Empire of Nicaea after Fourth Crusade; restored Constantinople in 1261.

name: Early Viking Age
region: Northern Europe, Western Europe, Eastern Europe
notes: Well-documented via archaeology, runestones, sagas, and foreign chronicles; leadership structures varied by region.

name: County of Portugal
notes: Founded by Vímara Peres as a vassal of León; evolved into the Kingdom of Portugal in 1139.

name: Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)
notes: Well-documented medieval kingdom; sources include chronicles, charters, and archaeological finds.

name: Principality of Hungary
notes: Founded by Magyars; transition from pagan tribal federation to Christian monarchy under Stephen I.

name: Dynasty of Larsa
notes: Well-documented Sumerian dynasty; rivals of Isin, later conquered by Hammurabi of Babylon.

name: Sidon
notes: Major Phoenician city; famed for purple dye, glassmaking, and trade. Conquered by Persians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs.

name: Tyre
notes: Phoenician city-state, famed for trade and purple dye; conquered by Alexander the Great in 332 BCE.

name: Himyarite Kingdom
notes: South Arabian kingdom in Yemen; known for trade, inscriptions, and Jewish conversion under King Dhu Nuwas.

name: Ghassanid Kingdom
notes: Arab Christian kingdom allied with Byzantines; capital at Jabiyah; buffer against Sassanids and nomads.

name: Ghurid Sultanate
region: Asia, Middle East, South Asia, Central Asia
notes: Persianate Sunni Muslim dynasty; expanded from Ghor (Afghanistan) into Iran, N. India. Key in Delhi Sultanate's rise.

name: Buyid Dynasty
notes: Persian Shi'a dynasty ruling parts of Iran and Iraq; notable for cultural revival and political fragmentation.

name: Ghaznavid Empire
region: Asia, Middle East, South Asia, Central Asia
notes: Turko-Persian dynasty; major role in Islamic expansion into India. Noted for raids, architecture, and Persianate culture.

name: Gandhara
notes: Renowned for Greco-Buddhist art; ruled by various dynasties including Achaemenids, Mauryans, Kushans.

name: Harsha Empire
notes: Ruled by Harsha; sources include Chinese pilgrim Xuanzang. Known for patronage of arts and Buddhism.

name: Eastern Chalukya
notes: Ruled eastern Deccan, India; notable for patronage of Telugu and Sanskrit literature; capital at Vengi.

name: Later Pandya Kingdom
notes: Tamil dynasty in southern India, revived after Sangam era; known for trade, temples, and conflicts with Cholas and foreign invaders.

name: Khilji Dynasty
notes: Turkic dynasty ruling Delhi Sultanate; notable for Alauddin Khilji's reforms and Mongol invasions.

name: Lodi Dynasty
notes: Afghan dynasty ruling Delhi Sultanate; ended by Babur at First Battle of Panipat.

name: Bengal Sultanate
notes: Prominent medieval Islamic state in Bengal; rich in architecture, literature, and trade.

name: Western Zhou
notes: Western Zhou established feudal order, known for bronze artifacts and early Chinese classics.

name: Xin Dynasty
notes: Short-lived Chinese dynasty under Wang Mang; well-documented in Han sources.

name: Eastern Jin
notes: Founded by Sima Rui after Western Jin collapse; known for court intrigue, southern migration, and cultural achievements.

name: Later Jin
notes: Founded by Shi Jingtang, vassal of Liao; short-lived, part of Five Dynasties period in China.

name: Former Shu
notes: Former Shu was a short-lived kingdom during China's Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period, centered in Sichuan.

name: Majapahit Empire
notes: Centered in Java, Majapahit was a major thalassocratic empire; sources include Nagarakretagama and Chinese records.

name: Malacca Sultanate
notes: Key maritime power; rich Malay, Islamic, and trade influences; fell to Portuguese in 1511.

name: Aceh Sultanate
notes: Prominent Islamic sultanate in northern Sumatra; known for trade, scholarship, and resistance to colonial powers.

name: Terminal Classic Maya
notes: Period marked by political fragmentation, city abandonment, and cultural transformation in southern lowlands.

name: Pioneer Period
notes: Refers to westward expansion and settlement by European-descended Americans in the US.

name: Tupua Tamasese Dynasty
notes: Key chiefly family in Samoa; prominent in anti-colonial Mau movement and Samoan independence.

name: Classic Māori Tribal Period
notes: Rich oral tradition, strong archaeological record, but limited written sources before European contact.

name: Tyrian Colony of Carthage
notes: Founded by Phoenicians from Tyre; major Mediterranean power; destroyed by Rome in Third Punic War.

name: Luxembourg Dynasty
notes: Dynasty of Holy Roman Emperors and kings, notably Charles IV. Extensive documentation in European archives.

name: Kingdom of Northumbria
notes: Anglo-Saxon kingdom in northern England; sources include Bede, archaeology, and later chronicles.

name: Kingdom of Poland (Angevin dynasty)
notes: Ruled by Louis I of Hungary; brief period, well-documented in Polish and Hungarian sources.

name: Old Swiss Confederacy
notes: Loose alliance of cantons; direct democracy elements; dissolved by French invasion (Helvetic Republic).

name: Khwarazmian Empire
notes: Turko-Persian dynasty, fell to Mongols. Good records on rulers and events, moderate on daily life and artifacts.

name: Magadha
notes: Major ancient Indian kingdom; key in rise of Buddhism and Jainism. Sources: Pali, Sanskrit, Greek, and archaeological finds.

name: Kushan Empire
notes: Flourished under Kanishka; key role in Silk Road trade and Buddhist transmission.

name: Jadeja Dynasty
notes: Rajput dynasty ruling parts of Gujarat, notably Kutch and Nawanagar, with well-documented rulers and cultural legacy.

name: Ahom Kingdom
notes: Ruled Assam for nearly 600 years; known for Tai-Ahom culture and resisting Mughal invasions.

name: Zhao (Warring States period)
notes: Major Warring State in ancient China; well-documented in Chinese historical texts.

name: Wei (Warring States period)
notes: Wei was a major state during China's Warring States period, known for reforms and military conflicts.

name: Later Liang
notes: One of the Sixteen Kingdoms in northwestern China, founded by the Lü family of Di ethnicity.

name: Later Qin
notes: Xianbei-led dynasty in North China during Sixteen Kingdoms; notable for Buddhist patronage and political instability.

name: Chen dynasty
notes: Last of the Southern Dynasties in China; records exist but less material culture survives.

name: Jingnan
notes: Jingnan was a small kingdom during China's Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period.

name: Jin Dynasty (Jurchen)
notes: Jurchen-led dynasty in northern China, overthrown by Mongols; significant in Song and Mongol histories.

name: Hồ dynasty
notes: Short-lived Vietnamese dynasty; notable for reforms and resistance to Ming invasion.

name: Restored Lê dynasty
notes: Vietnamese dynasty; nominal rulers under Trịnh and Nguyễn lords, ended by Tây Sơn uprising.

name: Classic Period
notes: Refers mainly to the Maya civilization's peak; rich archaeology, glyphs partly deciphered.

name: Tuʻi Kanokupolu dynasty
notes: Tongan royal dynasty, established 17th century, still influential. Good oral and written records from 18th century onward.

name: Mata'afa Dynasty
notes: Samoan chiefly dynasty influential in late 19th–early 20th c. politics; key in Samoan civil wars and colonial encounters.

name: Mauretania Tingitana (Roman province)
notes: Roman province in NW Africa; capital Tingis (Tangier); Berber-Roman culture; annexed by Vandals in 429.

name: Pate Sultanate
notes: Swahili sultanate on Pate Island, Kenya. Known for trade, Islamic scholarship, and stone architecture.

name: Lamu Sultanate
notes: Swahili city-state on Lamu Island, known for trade, Islamic scholarship, and unique architecture.

name: Tewodrosid Restoration
notes: Refers to Emperor Tewodros II's reign and efforts to unify Ethiopia; well-documented in Ethiopian and foreign sources.

name: Mycenaean Greece
notes: Linear B tablets, palatial ruins, and rich grave goods provide strong evidence; collapse around 1100 BCE.

name: Archaic Greece
notes: Period of city-state formation, Homeric epics, and early colonization; sources include archaeology and later historians.

name: Visigothic Kingdom
notes: Ruled much of Iberia and parts of Gaul; sources include chronicles, law codes, and archaeology.

name: Hittite Old Kingdom
notes: Centered in Anatolia; cuneiform texts and royal lists survive. Early phase before empire expansion.

name: Byblos
notes: One of the oldest continuously inhabited cities; key Phoenician port; rich archaeological remains.

name: Berytus
notes: Berytus (modern Beirut) was a Roman colony, famed for its law school and Greco-Roman culture.

name: Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)
notes: Northern Israelite kingdom; Assyrian conquest ended it. Sources: Bible, Assyrian records, archaeology.

name: Kashi
notes: Kashi (Varanasi) is a continuously inhabited city, sacred in Hinduism, with rich cultural and religious history.

name: Satavahana Dynasty
notes: Major Deccan dynasty; known for Prakrit inscriptions, Buddhist monuments, and trade links.

name: Pallava Dynasty
notes: South Indian dynasty known for Dravidian architecture; inscriptions in Tamil, Sanskrit, Prakrit.

name: Sayyid Dynasty
notes: Delhi Sultanate dynasty of Persian origin; ruled northern India; succeeded by Lodi dynasty.

name: Paramara Dynasty
notes: Ruled Malwa region; most famous ruler was Bhoja. Good epigraphic and literary sources.

name: Spring and Autumn period
notes: Era of fragmented Zhou rule; rise of regional states, Confucius lived; sources include Zuo Zhuan and Shiji.

name: Qin (Warring States period)
notes: Qin was a major state in the Warring States period, later unifying China under Qin Shi Huang.

name: Yan (Warring States period)
notes: Yan was a major state in northern China; records from Chinese chronicles and archaeology exist.

name: Later Zhao
notes: Founded by Shi Le, a Jie-led dynasty during the Sixteen Kingdoms period in northern China.

name: Western Liang
notes: A minor dynasty during China's Sixteen Kingdoms; ruled by the Li family in modern Gansu.

name: Southern Liang
notes: A Xianbei-led dynasty in northwestern China during the Sixteen Kingdoms period.

name: Northern Han
notes: One of the Ten Kingdoms in China, ruled by the Liu family, conquered by Song dynasty.

name: Middle Silla
notes: Unified Silla period; notable for Buddhist culture, royal tombs, and consolidation of Korean peninsula.

name: Kofun Period
notes: Named for burial mounds; emergence of Yamato polity; Chinese and Korean sources mention Japan.

name: Yamato period
notes: Early Japanese state formation; archaeological and Chinese sources supplement local records.

name: Mạc dynasty
notes: Vietnamese dynasty; contested rule with Lê dynasty. Noted for civil war and administrative reforms.

name: Sukhothai Kingdom
notes: Early Thai kingdom, famed for art and Theravada Buddhism. Ramkhamhaeng stele is a key source.

name: Pagan Empire
notes: Centered in present-day Myanmar; known for Bagan temples and Theravada Buddhism.

name: Lan Xang Kingdom
notes: Powerful Lao kingdom; split into three after 1707. Buddhist culture, stone inscriptions, and chronicles survive.

name: Pueblo IV Era
notes: Marked by large pueblos, kivas, migrations, and Spanish contact. Rich archaeological remains.

name: Napatan Kingdom
notes: Kushite kingdom centered at Napata; known for pyramids, Egyptian influence, and rule over Egypt as 25th Dynasty.

name: Kingdom of Mauretania
notes: Berber kingdom, later Roman client state. Ruled by Juba II. Good Roman and Greek sources.

name: Etruscan City-States
notes: Etruscans influenced Roman culture; language partly undeciphered; known for art, tombs, and city-state structure.

name: Kingdom of Kent
notes: Early Anglo-Saxon kingdom in southeast England; sources include Bede and the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle.

name: Dynasty of Isin
notes: Sumerian dynasty post-Ur III; known from king lists, tablets, some archaeological remains.

name: Kassite Dynasty
notes: Kassites ruled Babylonia post-Hittite sack; records in Akkadian, Kassite language poorly attested.

name: Kingdom of Judah
notes: Biblical and archaeological sources; destroyed by Babylonians. Some debate over early history.

name: Kingdom of Aram-Damascus
notes: Aramaic-speaking kingdom centered on Damascus; fell to Assyria. Known from biblical, Assyrian, and archaeological sources.

name: Lydian Kingdom
notes: Known for early coinage, ruled by kings like Croesus, conquered by Persia. Sources: Herodotus, archaeology.

name: Kara-Khanid Khanate
notes: Turkic Muslim dynasty, notable for Islamization of Central Asia and rivalry with Ghaznavids and Seljuks.

name: Kulasekhara dynasty
notes: Ruled Kerala; notable for patronage of literature and temples. Sources include inscriptions and later chronicles.

name: Chandra Dynasty
notes: Likely refers to Gupta Dynasty, sometimes called Chandragupta dynasty after its founder.

name: Han (Warring States period)
notes: Han was one of the seven major states during China's Warring States period, later conquered by Qin.

name: Former Qin
notes: Founded by the Di ethnic group, Former Qin briefly unified northern China before its collapse after the Battle of Fei River.

name: Balhae
notes: Multi-ethnic kingdom in Manchuria and northern Korea; sources from China, Korea, Japan.

name: Đinh dynasty
notes: First imperial dynasty of Vietnam; founded by Đinh Bộ Lĩnh after unifying the country.

name: Kediri Kingdom
notes: Javanese kingdom known from inscriptions and literature; notable for literary works and trade.

name: Bruneian Sultanate
notes: Islamic sultanate on Borneo; peak in 15th-17th c.; vassalage to British in 1888.

name: Postclassic Huastec Period
notes: Huastec culture thrived on Gulf coast; known for ceramics, music, and contact with Aztecs before Spanish conquest.

name: Muisca Confederation
notes: Well-documented by Spanish sources; known for goldwork, salt production, and complex chiefdoms.

name: Haudenosaunee Confederacy
notes: Also known as the Iroquois Confederacy; influential in colonial-era diplomacy and governance.

name: Tuʻi Tonga Empire
notes: Dominant maritime polity in Polynesia; oral traditions and archaeology support its influence.

name: Tuimaleali'ifano Dynasty
notes: One of Samoa's four paramount chiefly dynasties; oral histories and colonial records document its influence.

name: Ancient Hawaiian Chiefdoms
notes: Chiefdoms unified under Kamehameha I by 1810. Oral traditions, archaeology, and early European accounts are main sources.
